Answer: Evolution happens to populations over generations. So this question isn’t about “evolution”. It’s about using technology toHuman technology has already affected humans to a large degree. The technology of sanitation has eliminated or drastically reduced outbreaks of infectious diseases. When was the last time you heard about a cholera or typhoid outbreak in the western world? Or even the entire world? Vaccination has boosted our immune systems to the point that we do not get measles, smallpox, mumps, or even tetanus.Modern agriculture, food distribution, animalEvolution happens to populations over generations. So this question isn’t about “evolution”. It’s about using technology toHuman technology has already affected humans to a large degree. The technology of sanitation has eliminated or drastically reduced outbreaks of infectious diseases. When was the last time you heard about a cholera or typhoid outbreak in the western world? Or even the entire world? Vaccination has boosted our immune systems to the point that we do not get measles, smallpox, mumps, or even tetanus.Modern agriculture, food distribution, animal husbandry, etc. have provided proper nutrition so that our physiology is working at near optimum. No scurvy, beri-beri, rickets, or general malnourishment. Of course, the use of lead based paint, faulty water supplies, and the widespread use of leaded gasoline has put lead into our environment so that the neural physiology of a significant number of people have been affected by lead poisoning.Bottom line, human technology has already influenced human physiology. How will that continue in the future? Depends on what technology is adopted and what its intended, and unintended, effects are. No one thought widespread use of asbestos would alter our physiology to produce mesothelioma, but it did. Nor did people think that widespread use of the technology of cigarette manufacture would affect lung physiology like it did.

question: https://www.quora.com/How-will-our-ever-developing-technology-begin-to-evolve-the-physiology-of-humans

Answer: Evolution is such a fundamentally slow process that human beings haven’t evolved since before the time of the Pharaohs.If you took an average human from the time of the Pharaohs and compared them to an average human today, there would be many differences. Humans today are taller, stronger, and heavier than back then; mostly because we are better nourished and therefore grow more fully. We also live longer because of clean water, good housing, and the availability of medical care.But none of this is due to evolution! These are all a result of environmental changes, not changes in DNA.

question: https://www.quora.com/How-will-our-ever-developing-technology-begin-to-evolve-the-physiology-of-humans

Answer: So where did your delusion that human evolution stopped when humans started using tools and technology come from? The paleontological evidence shows early stone tools in layers associated with early hominids, a quick Google search will give you loads of detail on this. If we restrict ourselves to Homo Sapiens (modern man), genetic evidence shows adaptations to a high cereal diet and adults drinking milk, a response to the move from hunter/gatherer to agricultural or pastural societies. Changing technologies doesn’t stop evolution, it simply modifies the evolutionary pressures for any one populSo where did your delusion that human evolution stopped when humans started using tools and technology come from? The paleontological evidence shows early stone tools in layers associated with early hominids, a quick Google search will give you loads of detail on this. If we restrict ourselves to Homo Sapiens (modern man), genetic evidence shows adaptations to a high cereal diet and adults drinking milk, a response to the move from hunter/gatherer to agricultural or pastural societies. Changing technologies doesn’t stop evolution, it simply modifies the evolutionary pressures for any one population.With the exception of organisms in the process of going extinct, all species, us included, are transitional between our precursor species and whatever they will become in the future.
